[[Image:Brandt Józef Pospolite ruszenie u brodu.jpg|thumb|350px|[[Józef Brandt]], ''Pospolite Ruszenie'' at a River Ford'', 1880]] '''''Pospolite ruszenie''''' ({{IPA-pl|pɔspɔˈlitɛ ruˈʂɛɲɛ}}, lit. ''mass mobilization''; "Noble Host",<ref name="Davies2005"/> {{lang-lat|motio belli}},<ref name="Gloger1896"/> the [[French language|French]] term ''[[levée en masse]]'' is also used<ref name="Davies2007"/>) is a name for the [[mobilisation]] of [[armed forces]] during the period of the [[Kingdom of Poland (1385–1569)|Kingdom of Poland]] and the [[Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth]]. The tradition of wartime mobilisation of part of the population existed from before the 13th century to the 19th century. In the later era, ''pospolite ruszenie'' units were formed from the ''[[szlachta]]'' (Polish "nobility"). The ''pospolite ruszenie'' was eventually outclassed by professional forces.
==Rise == Before the 13th century, the [[feudal levy]] of [[knight]]s was the customary method employed in the raising of Polish armies in the [[Kingdom of Poland (1385–1569)|Kingdom of Poland]] of the [[Late Middle Ages]].<ref name="Gloger1896"/><ref name="bardach113"/> The earliest mentions of the term can be traced to the reign of [[Władysław I the Elbow-high]] (1320–1333).<ref name="Gloger1896"/> [[Statutes of Casimir the Great]] made the service in the military obligatory for all knights-[[landowners]], under the penalty of land confiscation.<ref name="bardach113"/> The more wealthy knights provided a [[lances fournies]] unit (known in Poland as ''kopia''), and the less prosperous ones served as a [[light cavalry|light horseman]] or even [[infantryman]].<ref name="bardach113"/> They were obliged to take arms and defend the country, and to participate in wars in foreign lands.<ref name="bardach113"/>
As the knights (later, nobles - the [[szlachta]] class) started [[szlachta's privileges|to acquire privileges]], some of them began to change the way that the ''pospolite ruszenie'' functioned.<ref name="bardach113"/><ref name="bardach9192"/> The length of the service was set at two weeks.<ref name="Szela̜gowski1904">{{cite book|author=Adam Szela̜gowski|title=Wzrost państwa polskiego w XV i XVI w. Polska na przełomie wieków średnich i nowych|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rdERAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA319|accessdate=16 April 2012|year=1904|publisher=Nakł. B. Połonieckiego|pages=318–321}}</ref> The [[Privilege of Buda]] of 1355 required the king to compensate any losses incurred by the nobles in wars abroad, and the [[Privilege of Koszyce]] of 1374 required him to pay the ransom for any nobles taken into captivity during wars abroad.<ref name="bardach113"/><ref name="bardach9192"/> A privilege of 1388 extended that compensation for losses incurred when defending the country and confirmed that the nobles were to receive a monetary wage for their participation and that they should be consulted with by the king beforehand.<ref name="bardach113"/>
The early ''pospolite ruszenie'' also put the requirement of military service on the landowning knights in the priesthood, and on the peasant leaders ([[sołtys]] and [[wójt]]s).<ref name="bardach113"/> The few townsfolk who owned land estates would also have the obligation to serve.<ref name="Gloger1896"/> It could be called by the king, or in his absence and in dire need, from the 14th century, the [[starost]] of the affected territory.<ref name="bardach113"/> From 1454 another privilege (the [[Privilege of Cerkwica]], confirmed the same year by the [[Statutes of Nieszawa]]) made the calling of a pospolite ruszenie conditional on the agreement of the local [[sejmik]] (regional parliament) and, by the end of the 15th century, this required the agreement of the national parliament, the [[sejm]].<ref name="bardach113"/><ref name="bardach9192"/><ref name="bardach229"/> Some of the above privileges were extorted by the szlachta from the king, as a ''pospolite ruszenie'' was known to refuse to act unless more privileges were granted to it (this was the case, for example, in 1454).<ref name="FedorowiczBogucka1982"/><ref name="Davies1982"/><ref name="Zielinski1918"/>
''Pospolite ruszenie'' units were usually organized based on a [[Administrative division of the Kingdom of Poland|territorial and administrative division of Kingdom of Poland]] (later, the [[Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth]]), within units known as [[voivodeship]]s (Latin 'palatinate'), and smaller ones.<ref name="bardach113"/> The knights (nobles) would be gathered by [[castellans]] and [[voivode]]s, who led them to the chosen points where the command would pass to the military commanders ([[hetmans]]) or the king.<ref name="bardach113"/> The units would be organized into units of about 50-120 strong ([[chorągiew]]), based on their territorial origin.<ref name="bardach113"/> There were some exceptions, as the most powerful [[magnate]]s would form their own chorągiews.<ref name="bardach113"/>
==Decline== ''Szlachta'' from regions like the Commonwealth's eastern and southern borderlands, where combat was common, created fairly competent units, while those from peaceful regions of the Commonwealth lacked battle experience and training compared to regular-military troops or [[mercenary|mercenaries]]. In time, ''pospolite ruszenie'' became increasingly amateurish and inefficient when compared to professional soldiers; Bardach notes that this process can be seen as early as the [[Thirteen Years' War (1454–66)]].<ref name="bardach229"/> In addition to the lack of training, discipline and unstandardized equipment, the time it took for a pospolite ruszenie to be called to arms and gathered in a designed spot (often, close to a month) was also a problem.<ref name="Szela̜gowski1904"/> Some attempts at reform the situation, including a mass wave of estate confiscations at 1497, and a requirement for yearly gatherings and reviews, did little to ameliorate the situation.<ref name="bardach229"/><ref name="Bush1988"/>
From the 15th century, ''pospolite ruszenie'' levies were used less often than were professional military [[troop]]s.<ref name="Szela̜gowski1904"/><ref name="Bush1988"/> By mid-16th century, pospolite ruszenie could, in theory, have fielded about 50,000 troops.<ref name="Davies2007"/>
By the 17th century, the military value of the ''pospolite ruszenie'' was very limited, and was last called to participate in the [[Battle of Warsaw (1656)|Battle of Warsaw]] of 1656 during [[Deluge (history)|The Deluge]] (the battle ended with a Polish defeat).<ref name="bardach229"/> Nonetheless, the ''szlachta'' continued to believe they formed an elite army, and that their participation in the defense of the country was an important reason for [[Golden Freedoms|their privileged position]] in it.<ref name="bardach229"/><ref name="LukowskiZawadzki2006"/> As this was used as a justifications for lower taxation, the Commonwealth treasury found itself increasingly starved for funds to pay to regular, standing army.<ref name="bardach229"/> With the Commonwealth Army reduced by that time to around 16,000, it was easy for its neighbors to overpower its armies (the [[Imperial Russian Army]] numbered 300,000; the [[Prussian Army]] and [[Imperial Austrian Army]], 200,000).<ref name="Bauer1991"/>
==Final reforms, partitions and the Second Polish Republic== During the [[Kościuszko Uprising]] in 1794, under the influence of [[revolutionary France]] and [[Age of Enlightenment|Enlightenment]] ideas about the role of the [[militia]], ''pospolite ruszenie'' was redefined as consisted of not only the nobility, but all able-bodied males between 18 and 40 years of age.<ref name="WIEM"/><ref name="Palmer1970"/> In 1806, by decree of [[Napoleon]], the ''pospolite ruszenie'' in the [[Duchy of Warsaw]] served for a short period as the [[Military reserve force|reserve]] force and recruitment pool for the [[regular army]].<ref name=WIEM/> During the [[November Uprising]] in 1831, the ''[[Sejm]]'' (Polish Parliament) called for ''pospolite ruszenie'' recruits from the ages of 17 to 50, but that plan was opposed by General [[Jan Zygmunt Skrzynecki]].<ref name=WIEM/>
During the [[Second Republic of Poland]] (1918–1939), the ''pospolite ruszenie'' consisted of reserve soldiers, aged 40–50 and officers, aged 50–60.<ref name=WIEM/><ref name="Lerski1996"/> They were required to participate in [[military exercise|army exercises]] and to serve in armed forces during times of war.<ref name=WIEM/> <!--In mobilization schemes, the ''pospolite ruszenie'' was utilized as the "third wave" of troops arriving to the [[Front (military)|front]].-->
